title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: vignette walks DIAMOND RBH + Expansion clustering algorithm step step, using real data known fungal orthologs. Instead describing algorithms conceptually, show exactly happens stage actual sequence data.
code: library(paneffectR) library(dplyr) library(tidyr) library(ggplot2)

title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: use 16 well-characterized proteins three fungal species known orthology relationships: dataset includes: 3 species: S. cerevisiae (budding yeast), S. pombe (fission yeast), N. crassa (bread mold) 5 conserved protein families: actin, GAPDH, histone H3, EF-1α, cytochrome c 1 species-specific singleton: mating pheromone MFA1 (S. cerevisiae) Ground truth: expected orthogroup assignments
code: # Load the protein collection clustering_dir <- system.file("testdata", "clustering", package = "paneffectR") proteins <- readRDS(file.path(clustering_dir, "known_orthologs.rds"))  # Load expected relationships (ground truth) expected <- read.csv(file.path(clustering_dir, "expected_orthogroups.csv"))  # Summary proteins #> -- protein_collection -- #> 3 assemblies, 16 total proteins #>  #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>   assembly_name n_proteins has_scores #>   <chr>              <int> <lgl>      #> 1 ncra                   5 FALSE      #> 2 scer                   6 FALSE      #> 3 spom                   5 FALSE expected |>   select(protein_id, assembly, expected_og, protein_name) |>   knitr::kable(caption = "Ground truth: expected orthogroup assignments")

title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: first step runs DIAMOND blastp compare every protein every protein. produces table sequence similarity hits. paneffectR runs DIAMOND custom output format get columns needed filtering RBH detection: DIAMOND output computed coverage
code: diamond blastp -d db -q proteins.faa -o hits.tsv \   --outfmt 6 qseqid sseqid pident length qlen evalue bitscore # Load pre-computed DIAMOND results diamond_hits <- readRDS(file.path(clustering_dir, "diamond_hits.rds"))  # Show structure cat("Total hits (excluding self-hits):", nrow(diamond_hits), "\n\n") #> Total hits (excluding self-hits): 30 head(diamond_hits, 10) |>   knitr::kable(digits = 2, caption = "DIAMOND output with computed coverage")

title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: DIAMOND directly (7 columns): Computed paneffectR (1 column): Note: differs default BLAST tabular format, includes alignment coordinates (qstart, qend, sstart, send) gap information (mismatch, gapopen). request columns needed clustering.

title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: heatmap reveals clear ortholog groups: proteins family (e.g., three actins) cluster together high scores, unrelated proteins show hits. Note: singleton scer_MFA1 (mating pheromone) absent plot significant hits protein - exactly end singleton final clustering.
code: # Get best hit between each pair best_hits <- diamond_hits |>   group_by(qseqid, sseqid) |>   slice_max(bitscore, n = 1) |>   ungroup()  # Order proteins by protein family (expected_og) to reveal ortholog blocks protein_order <- expected |>   arrange(expected_og, assembly) |>   pull(protein_id)  # Convert to long format for ggplot with family-based ordering plot_data <- best_hits |>   mutate(     qseqid = factor(qseqid, levels = protein_order),     sseqid = factor(sseqid, levels = protein_order)   )  ggplot(plot_data, aes(x = sseqid, y = qseqid, fill = bitscore)) +   geom_tile() +   scale_fill_viridis_c(name = "Bitscore") +    theme_minimal() +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1, size = 8),         axis.text.y = element_text(size = 8)) +   labs(x = "Subject", y = "Query",        title = "DIAMOND blastp hit scores (ordered by protein family)",        subtitle = "Diagonal blocks show orthologs with high similarity")

title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: hits meaningful. apply thresholds keep significant matches: case, hits pass filters well-conserved proteins high sequence similarity.
code: # Load filtered hits hits_filtered <- readRDS(file.path(clustering_dir, "diamond_hits_filtered.rds"))  cat("Before filtering:", nrow(diamond_hits), "hits\n") #> Before filtering: 30 hits cat("After filtering: ", nrow(hits_filtered), "hits\n") #> After filtering:  30 hits

title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: reciprocal best hit (RBH) two proteins ’s best match. stringent criterion orthology: Find protein ’s best hit → B Find protein B’s best hit → back ? yes, B reciprocal best hits 30 filtered hits, paneffectR identified 5 RBH pairs: Reciprocal best hit pairs identified
code: rbh_pairs <- readRDS(file.path(clustering_dir, "rbh_pairs.rds"))  rbh_pairs |>   knitr::kable(caption = "Reciprocal best hit pairs identified")

what: Why not all orthologs form RBH pairs
title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: Let’s trace example RBH fails connect obvious orthologs. Question: scer_ACT1 (yeast actin) RBH pair ncra_act (N. crassa actin)? Step 1: Find scer_ACT1’s best hit. best hit (highest bitscore) ncra_act score 708. Step 2: Check reverse - ncra_act’s best hit? best hit ncra_act spom_act1 (score 716), scer_ACT1 (score 709). Result: scer_ACT1 → ncra_act, ncra_act → spom_act1. relationship reciprocal, RBH pair. illustrates limitation pure RBH: scer_ACT1 clear actin ortholog, ncra_act slightly similar spom_act1, yeast actin gets left RBH network. expansion phase (Step 5) rescue .
code: scer_act1_hits <- hits_filtered |>   filter(qseqid == "scer_ACT1") |>   arrange(desc(bitscore))  scer_act1_hits |>   select(qseqid, sseqid, pident, bitscore) |>   knitr::kable() ncra_act_hits <- hits_filtered |>   filter(qseqid == "ncra_act") |>   arrange(desc(bitscore))  ncra_act_hits |>   select(qseqid, sseqid, pident, bitscore) |>   knitr::kable()

title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: 5 RBH pairs 15 orthologous proteins, ’re clearly missing connections. see pattern, let’s visualize species linked RBH protein family. figure shows 5 RBH pairs lines connecting proteins across species. column protein family, row species. Notice RBH pairs connect two species time - fundamental limitation expansion phase addresses.  Notice RBH pairs connect two species time. fundamental limitation pure RBH: can’t directly identify orthogroups spanning three species.
code: # Get protein positions for network layout protein_positions <- expected |>   filter(expected_og != "singleton") |>   mutate(     x = as.numeric(factor(expected_og)),     y = as.numeric(factor(assembly, levels = c("ncra", "spom", "scer")))   )  # Plot ggplot() +   # Add edges for RBH pairs   geom_segment(     data = rbh_pairs |>       left_join(protein_positions |> select(protein_id, x, y),                 by = c("protein_a" = "protein_id")) |>       rename(x1 = x, y1 = y) |>       left_join(protein_positions |> select(protein_id, x, y),                 by = c("protein_b" = "protein_id")) |>       rename(x2 = x, y2 = y),     aes(x = x1, y = y1, xend = x2, yend = y2),     color = "steelblue", linewidth = 1.5, alpha = 0.6   ) +   # Add protein points   geom_point(data = protein_positions,              aes(x = x, y = y, color = assembly),              size = 4) +   geom_text(data = protein_positions,             aes(x = x, y = y, label = protein_id),             size = 2.5, vjust = -1) +   scale_y_continuous(     breaks = 1:3,     labels = c("N. crassa", "S. pombe", "S. cerevisiae")   ) +   scale_x_continuous(     breaks = 1:5,     labels = c("actin", "cyc", "ef1a", "gapdh", "h3")   ) +   scale_color_manual(values = c(ncra = "#E69F00", spom = "#56B4E9", scer = "#009E73")) +   theme_minimal() +   labs(title = "RBH pairs connect proteins across species",        subtitle = "Lines show reciprocal best hit relationships",        x = "Protein family", y = NULL) +   theme(legend.position = "none",         panel.grid.minor = element_blank())

title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: RBH pairs form “seeds” orthogroups. find connected components RBH graph: proteins linked chain RBH pairs form one group. Seed orthogroups RBH connected components seed phase: 5 orthogroups 10 proteins (2 proteins ) 6 singletons: proteins RBH pair Seed orthogroup composition actins (scer_ACT1), GAPDH (ncra_gpd1), cytochrome c (scer_CYC1), EF-1α (ncra_tef1), histone H3 (spom_hht1) singletons - weren’t part RBH pair even though clear orthologs!
code: orthogroups_seed <- readRDS(file.path(clustering_dir, "orthogroups_seed.rds"))  orthogroups_seed |>   arrange(orthogroup_id, protein_id) |>   knitr::kable(caption = "Seed orthogroups from RBH connected components") seed_summary <- orthogroups_seed |>   group_by(orthogroup_id) |>   summarize(n_proteins = n(), proteins = paste(protein_id, collapse = ", "))  seed_summary |>   knitr::kable(caption = "Seed orthogroup composition") # List singletons all_proteins_list <- unlist(lapply(proteins$assemblies, function(ps) ps$proteins$protein_id)) singletons <- setdiff(all_proteins_list, orthogroups_seed$protein_id) cat("\nSingletons after seed phase:", paste(singletons, collapse = ", "), "\n") #>  #> Singletons after seed phase: ncra_gpd1, ncra_tef1, scer_ACT1, scer_CYC1, scer_MFA1, spom_hht1

title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: expansion phase addresses RBH limitation adding singletons existing orthogroups best hit already cluster member: singleton, find best hit hit orthogroup, add singleton group Repeat proteins can added

what: The DIAMOND hits behind RBH pairs
title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: First, let’s see actual DIAMOND output rows support 5 RBH pairs. RBH pair, directions must best hits: DIAMOND hits RBH pairs (directions) protein RBH pair top hit (highest bitscore).
code: # Get the DIAMOND hits that form RBH pairs # For each RBH pair, show both directions from the original DIAMOND output rbh_evidence <- rbh_pairs |>   rowwise() |>   mutate(     # Get hit A -> B     hit_ab = list(hits_filtered |>       filter(qseqid == protein_a, sseqid == protein_b) |>       select(qseqid, sseqid, pident, bitscore)),     # Get hit B -> A     hit_ba = list(hits_filtered |>       filter(qseqid == protein_b, sseqid == protein_a) |>       select(qseqid, sseqid, pident, bitscore))   ) |>   ungroup()  # Combine into one table rbh_hits <- bind_rows(   bind_rows(rbh_evidence$hit_ab),   bind_rows(rbh_evidence$hit_ba) ) |>   arrange(qseqid, desc(bitscore))  rbh_hits |>   knitr::kable(     caption = "DIAMOND hits for RBH pairs (both directions)",     col.names = c("Query", "Subject", "% Identity", "Bitscore"),     digits = 1   )

title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: Now let’s see DIAMOND evidence expansion. singleton’s best hit must existing cluster: DIAMOND hits singletons (top 2 per singleton) singleton, best hit (highest bitscore) already seed cluster, singleton joins cluster. Expansion decisions: singleton joins cluster via best hit
code: expansion_trace <- readRDS(file.path(clustering_dir, "expansion_trace.rds"))  # For each singleton, show its DIAMOND hits (best hit first) singletons_list <- expansion_trace$singleton  singleton_hits <- hits_filtered |>   filter(qseqid %in% singletons_list) |>   group_by(qseqid) |>   arrange(desc(bitscore)) |>   slice_head(n = 2) |>  # Show top 2 hits for context   ungroup() |>   select(qseqid, sseqid, pident, bitscore)  # Add cluster membership info clustered_proteins <- orthogroups_seed$protein_id singleton_hits <- singleton_hits |>   mutate(     hit_in_cluster = ifelse(sseqid %in% clustered_proteins, "Yes", "No")   )  singleton_hits |>   knitr::kable(     caption = "DIAMOND hits from singletons (top 2 per singleton)",     col.names = c("Singleton", "Hit", "% Identity", "Bitscore", "Hit in cluster?"),     digits = 1   ) # Summarize the joins expansion_trace |>   select(singleton, best_hit, best_hit_bitscore, target_cluster) |>   knitr::kable(     caption = "Expansion decisions: singleton joins cluster via best hit",     col.names = c("Singleton", "Best hit", "Bitscore", "Joins cluster"),     digits = 0   )

title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: network shows DIAMOND scores connect proteins. Edge thickness labels show bitscores DIAMOND output. Blue edges RBH pairs (seeds); orange edges show expansion connections.  network naturally clusters 5 groups (orthogroups). Proteins high DIAMOND scores pulled together. Notice orthogroup 3 members connected mix RBH (seed) expansion edges.
code: library(igraph)  # Build edges from RBH pairs with their DIAMOND scores rbh_with_scores <- rbh_pairs |>   left_join(     hits_filtered |> select(qseqid, sseqid, bitscore),     by = c("protein_a" = "qseqid", "protein_b" = "sseqid")   ) |>   left_join(     hits_filtered |> select(qseqid, sseqid, bitscore),     by = c("protein_a" = "sseqid", "protein_b" = "qseqid"),     suffix = c("", "_rev")   ) |>   mutate(bitscore = coalesce(bitscore, bitscore_rev)) |>   select(from = protein_a, to = protein_b, bitscore) |>   mutate(type = "RBH (seed)")  # Expansion edges already have scores expansion_with_scores <- expansion_trace |>   select(from = singleton, to = best_hit, bitscore = best_hit_bitscore) |>   mutate(type = "Expansion")  # Combine all edges all_edges <- bind_rows(rbh_with_scores, expansion_with_scores)  # Get node info (exclude singleton MFA1 which has no edges) nodes <- expected |>   filter(expected_og != "singleton") |>   select(protein_id, assembly, expected_og)  # Create igraph object g <- graph_from_data_frame(all_edges, directed = FALSE, vertices = nodes)  # Use Fruchterman-Reingold layout for natural clustering set.seed(42) layout <- layout_with_fr(g) # Scale up to increase distance between nodes layout <- layout * 2 layout_df <- as.data.frame(layout) names(layout_df) <- c("x", "y") layout_df$protein_id <- V(g)$name  # Add node attributes layout_df <- layout_df |>   left_join(nodes, by = "protein_id")  # Prepare edge coordinates edge_df <- all_edges |>   left_join(layout_df |> select(protein_id, x, y), by = c("from" = "protein_id")) |>   rename(x1 = x, y1 = y) |>   left_join(layout_df |> select(protein_id, x, y), by = c("to" = "protein_id")) |>   rename(x2 = x, y2 = y) |>   mutate(     xmid = (x1 + x2) / 2,     ymid = (y1 + y2) / 2,     score_label = round(bitscore)   )  # Plot ggplot() +   # RBH edges (solid, fixed width)   geom_segment(     data = filter(edge_df, type == "RBH (seed)"),     aes(x = x1, y = y1, xend = x2, yend = y2),     color = "steelblue", linewidth = 1.5, alpha = 0.8   ) +   # Expansion edges (dashed, fixed width)   geom_segment(     data = filter(edge_df, type == "Expansion"),     aes(x = x1, y = y1, xend = x2, yend = y2),     color = "darkorange", linewidth = 1.5, linetype = "dashed", alpha = 0.8   ) +   # Protein nodes (large)   geom_point(     data = layout_df,     aes(x = x, y = y, color = assembly),     size = 14   ) +   # Protein labels (inside nodes)   geom_text(     data = layout_df,     aes(x = x, y = y, label = protein_id),     size = 4.4, fontface = "bold", color = "black"   ) +   # Edge score labels   geom_text(     data = edge_df,     aes(x = xmid, y = ymid, label = score_label),     size = 6, fontface = "bold"   ) +   scale_color_manual(     values = c(ncra = "#E69F00", spom = "#56B4E9", scer = "#009E73"),     labels = c(ncra = "N. crassa", spom = "S. pombe", scer = "S. cerevisiae")   ) +   coord_cartesian(clip = "off") +   expand_limits(x = c(min(layout_df$x) - 0.5, max(layout_df$x) + 0.5),                 y = c(min(layout_df$y) - 0.5, max(layout_df$y) + 0.5)) +   theme_void() +   labs(     title = "Clustering network with DIAMOND bitscores",     subtitle = "Blue solid = RBH pairs (seed clusters), Orange dashed = expansion joins",     color = "Species"   ) +   theme(     legend.position = "bottom",     plot.title = element_text(hjust = 0.5, face = "bold"),     plot.subtitle = element_text(hjust = 0.5)   )

title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: Take scer_ACT1 example: ’s RBH pair (best hit ncra_act prefers spom_act1) ncra_act OG0001 (via RBH spom_act1) scer_ACT1 joins OG0001 best-hit connection “anchor expand” strategy lets orthogroups grow beyond strict RBH pairs maintaining high-confidence RBH relationships foundation. iteration 1, 5 “missing” orthologs found way home: 5 protein families now complete set 3 orthologs, scer_MFA1 correctly remains singleton.

# Show before and after with expected orthogroup names orthogroups_expanded <- readRDS(file.path(clustering_dir, "orthogroups_expanded.rds"))  # Add expected orthogroup info protein_info <- expected |>   select(protein_id, expected_og)  cat("=== Before Expansion (Seed Phase) ===

=== After Expansion ===

title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: Hits excluded 70% identity threshold GAPDH cytochrome c families cross-species identities around 63-69%, strict 70% threshold. proteins become incorrectly isolated singletons overly strict parameters.
code: # Find proteins that got excluded proteins_strict <- orthogroups_strict$protein_id proteins_default <- orthogroups_expanded$protein_id  newly_singletons <- setdiff(proteins_default, proteins_strict)  cat("Proteins excluded by strict parameters:\n") #> Proteins excluded by strict parameters: expected |>   filter(protein_id %in% newly_singletons) |>   select(protein_id, protein_name, expected_og) |>   knitr::kable() # Show the excluded hits hits_filtered |>   filter(!qseqid %in% proteins_strict | !sseqid %in% proteins_strict) |>   filter(qseqid %in% newly_singletons | sseqid %in% newly_singletons) |>   select(qseqid, sseqid, pident, bitscore) |>   distinct() |>   knitr::kable(caption = "Hits excluded by 70% identity threshold")

title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: orthogroups assigned, can build presence/absence matrix (rows = orthogroups, columns = assemblies). compare similar two assemblies based shared orthogroup content, need distance metric. used hierarchical clustering visualizations like dendrograms.

title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: Jaccard index measures similarity size intersection divided size union. distance 1 minus similarity, ignoring shared absences: dJaccard(,B)=1−|∩B||∪B|d_{Jaccard}(, B) = 1 - \frac{|\cap B|}{|\cup B|}
code: # Load example data from visual testdata visual_dir <- system.file("testdata", "visual", package = "paneffectR") pa <- readRDS(file.path(visual_dir, "pa_binary.rds"))  plot_dendro(pa, distance_method = "jaccard") +   ggtitle("Assembly clustering with Jaccard distance")

title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: Binary (Euclidean): Square root number orthogroups two assemblies differ. Bray-Curtis: Originally designed abundance data, works binary. See Wikipedia.

title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: computing distances, assemblies clustered hierarchically:
code: # Compare methods plot_dendro(pa, cluster_method = "complete") plot_dendro(pa, cluster_method = "average") plot_dendro(pa, cluster_method = "ward.D2")

title: Algorithms in paneffectR
text: Singletons proteins assigned orthogroup. may represent: True unique genes: Horizontally transferred, species-specific Divergent homologs: different pass similarity thresholds Artifacts: Mis-predicted ORFs, fragmented assemblies include singletons: - Analyzing unique gene content - Calculating pan-genome size - Studying accessory genome exclude singletons: - Focusing shared variation - Phylogenetic analysis - Reducing noise
code: # Using the visual test data visual_dir <- system.file("testdata", "visual", package = "paneffectR") clusters <- readRDS(file.path(visual_dir, "clusters_visual.rds"))  # Compare with and without singletons pa_with <- build_pa_matrix(clusters, exclude_singletons = FALSE) pa_without <- build_pa_matrix(clusters, exclude_singletons = TRUE)  cat("With singletons:", nrow(pa_with$matrix), "orthogroups\n") #> With singletons: 50 orthogroups cat("Without singletons:", nrow(pa_without$matrix), "orthogroups\n") #> Without singletons: 50 orthogroups

title: Effector Analysis with paneffectR
text: vignette demonstrates use paneffectR output omnieff effector prediction pipeline. key advantage ability filter effector prediction scores, focusing analysis high-confidence effector candidates.

title: Effector Analysis with paneffectR
text: omnieff runs multiple effector prediction tools combines results: Signal peptide predictors: SignalP 3/4/5/6, Phobius Effector predictors: EffectorP 1/2/3, DeepRedEff Localization: ApoplastP, Localizer Domain annotations: Pfam output includes: FASTA files (*_reformatted.faa): Protein sequences standardized names Score files (*_scored.csv): prediction scores plus combined custom_score Name mapping (*_name_mapping.csv): Links new names original contig names

title: Getting Started with paneffectR
text: paneffectR helps compare proteins across multiple genome assemblies. typical workflow : 1. Load protein sequences FASTA files 2. Cluster proteins orthogroups (groups equivalent proteins) 3. Build presence/absence matrix 4. Visualize results vignette walks step using example data included package.

title: Getting Started with paneffectR
code: library(paneffectR)

title: Getting Started with paneffectR
text: main entry point load_proteins(), discovers loads FASTA files directory: result protein_collection containing assemblies. can see: many assemblies loaded many proteins Whether effector scores present
code: # Get path to test data included with the package testdata_dir <- system.file("testdata", package = "paneffectR")  # Load all assemblies (FASTAs and scores) proteins <- load_proteins(   fasta_dir = testdata_dir,   score_dir = testdata_dir,   pattern = "*.faa" ) proteins #> -- protein_collection -- #> 3 assemblies, 300 total proteins #>  #> # A tibble: 3 × 3 #>   assembly_name n_proteins has_scores #>   <chr>              <int> <lgl>      #> 1 assembly1            100 TRUE       #> 2 assembly2            100 TRUE       #> 3 assembly3            100 TRUE

code: # Access one assembly ps <- proteins$assemblies[["assembly1"]] ps #> -- protein_set: assembly1 -- #> 100 proteins #> Scores: present  # The proteins are stored as a tibble head(ps$proteins[, c("protein_id", "sequence", "custom_score", "score_rank")]) #> # A tibble: 6 × 4 #>   protein_id       sequence                              custom_score score_rank #>   <chr>            <chr>                                        <dbl>      <int> #> 1 assembly1_000039 MPFVLNLLVLVAVWYGLVRMAMLLKDDSEIKSFDPF…         4.62         93 #> 2 assembly1_000040 MEVAECTHKLASTTFVKTVEAPALAIMEPLLKRALA…         4.75         64 #> 3 assembly1_000094 MTDKDKPKDDDDCYVKVNTPGGVGDTNSPNKGGLPF…         4.86         27 #> 4 assembly1_000122 MGSSPIFRPFKCKFSMFSKSILIFLLILPLISVILL…         4.81         44 #> 5 assembly1_000164 MLFCVMVGTGCQLLGMALVTLFFAAVGVLAPSNRGK…         4.78         54 #> 6 assembly1_000194 MMGNLAKDIVNGHREKTLALLWKLISCFQLQALVDA…         4.76         59

text: Now group proteins different assemblies orthogroups - sets proteins likely gene/function across assemblies. Note: Clustering requires DIAMOND installed. don’t DIAMOND, can skip step use pre-computed clusters included package visualization examples. vignette, ’ll load pre-computed results:

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
text: pan-genome represents complete gene content across set related genomes: Core genome: Genes present (nearly ) genomes - essential functions Accessory genome: Genes present genomes - niche adaptation, lifestyle Unique genes: Present one genome - strain-specific features paneffectR helps explore structure presence/absence analysis.

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
text: Calculate Jaccard similarity pairs:
code: # Simple Jaccard calculation jaccard <- function(a, b) {   intersection <- sum(a == 1 & b == 1)   union <- sum(a == 1 | b == 1)   intersection / union }  # Calculate for all pairs assemblies <- colnames(pa$matrix) n <- length(assemblies) sim_matrix <- matrix(0, n, n, dimnames = list(assemblies, assemblies))  for (i in 1:n) {   for (j in 1:n) {     sim_matrix[i, j] <- jaccard(pa$matrix[, i], pa$matrix[, j])   } }  round(sim_matrix, 2) #>       asm_A asm_B asm_C asm_D asm_E asm_F #> asm_A  1.00  0.49  0.50  0.53  0.44  0.33 #> asm_B  0.49  1.00  0.54  0.57  0.53  0.38 #> asm_C  0.50  0.54  1.00  0.46  0.46  0.43 #> asm_D  0.53  0.57  0.46  1.00  0.49  0.42 #> asm_E  0.44  0.53  0.46  0.49  1.00  0.59 #> asm_F  0.33  0.38  0.43  0.42  0.59  1.00

title: Pan-Genome Analysis with paneffectR
code: # Find most similar pair (excluding diagonal) sim_matrix_upper <- sim_matrix diag(sim_matrix_upper) <- 0 max_idx <- which(sim_matrix_upper == max(sim_matrix_upper), arr.ind = TRUE)[1, ]  cat("Most similar pair:",     assemblies[max_idx[1]], "and", assemblies[max_idx[2]],     "\nJaccard similarity:", round(max(sim_matrix_upper), 3), "\n") #> Most similar pair: asm_F and asm_E  #> Jaccard similarity: 0.588

title: paneffectR
text: Comparative genomics effector proteins across multiple genome assemblies.

title: paneffectR
text: studying plant pathogens, key question : effector proteins shared across isolates, unique? Understanding effector repertoires helps identify core virulence factors, track pathogen evolution, discover candidate avirulence genes. paneffectR solves : Clustering proteins orthogroups - Finding equivalent proteins across assemblies using sequence similarity Building presence/absence matrices - Creating structured data showing proteins exist assemblies Filtering effector scores - Focusing high-confidence effector predictions (using omnieff output) Generating publication-ready visualizations - Heatmaps, UpSet plots, dendrograms designed effector analysis, paneffectR works protein sets general pan-genome comparisons.

title: paneffectR
text: paneffectR requires Bioconductor packages. Install first: install paneffectR GitHub:
code: install.packages("BiocManager") BiocManager::install(c("ComplexHeatmap", "Biostrings")) # install.packages("devtools") devtools::install_github("TeamMacLean/paneffectR")

title: paneffectR
text: least one clustering tool must installed. DIAMOND recommended:

title: paneffectR
code: library(paneffectR)  # Load proteins from multiple assemblies proteins <- load_proteins(    fasta_dir = "path/to/fastas/",   score_dir = "path/to/scores/" )  # Cluster into orthogroups clusters <- cluster_proteins(proteins, method = "diamond_rbh")  # Build presence/absence matrix (filter to high-scoring effectors) pa <- build_pa_matrix(clusters, score_threshold = 5.0)  # Visualize ht <- plot_heatmap(pa) ComplexHeatmap::draw(ht)  plot_upset(pa, min_size = 2)

title: paneffectR
text: Take output omnieff pipeline, find orthologous effectors across assemblies, filter prediction confidence:
code: # Load omnieff output (FASTAs + scores) proteins <- load_proteins(   fasta_dir = "omnieff_output/reformatted/",   score_dir = "omnieff_output/scored/" )  # Cluster and build matrix with score threshold clusters <- cluster_proteins(proteins) pa <- build_pa_matrix(clusters, score_threshold = 5.0)  # Visualize effector repertoires plot_heatmap(pa) |> ComplexHeatmap::draw()

title: paneffectR
text: Compare protein sets without effector scores:
code: # Load raw FASTAs proteins <- load_proteins(fasta_dir = "my_assemblies/")  # Binary presence/absence analysis clusters <- cluster_proteins(proteins) pa <- build_pa_matrix(clusters, type = "binary")  # Identify core vs accessory proteins plot_upset(pa, min_size = 2) plot_dendro(pa, distance_method = "jaccard")
